case_title: REGISTERED FIRM SHEIKHAN INDUSTRIES, QUETTA vs WEST PAKISTAN INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION, KARACHI THROUGH ITS CHAIRMAN
respondant: WEST PAKISTAN INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION, KARACHI THROUGH ITS CHAIRMAN
complaint_summary: The plaintiff contested the forfeiture of Rs. 100,000 paid as a Call Deposit Receipt to the defendant, claiming it was independent of subsequent offers and not subject to conditions.
investigation_summary: The court examined the jurisdictional validity of the case and whether the cause of action arose within the Quetta Court's jurisdiction.
judgment_summary: The court ruled that the Quetta Court lacked jurisdiction as no part of the cause of action arose within its territory, and the defendant did not have a subordinate office in Quetta. The appeal was dismissed with no order as to costs.
legal_arguments: Plaintiff argued that under Section 20(c) of CPC, jurisdiction is established if part of the cause of action arises within the court's territory.
Defendant argued that Explanation II of Section 20 CPC requires both cause of action and a subordinate office within the court's jurisdiction.
key_issues: Jurisdiction of Quetta Court under Section 20 CPC
Interpretation of Explanation II of Section 20 CPC

maxims.Interpretation: Redundancy is not to be attributed to Legislatures.

legal_terms.Jurisdiction: The authority of a court to hear and decide a case.
legal_terms.Cause of Action: A set of facts sufficient to justify a right to sue.

words_and_phrases.Subordinate Office: An office under the principal office of a corporation within the jurisdiction of a court.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved jurisdictional challenges under Section 20 CPC, focusing on whether the Quetta Court could entertain the suit based on cause of action and the presence of a subordinate office. The appeal was dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction.

facts.initial_offer_details: Offer for purchase of majority shares in Harnai Woollen Mills, accompanied by a Call Deposit Receipt of Rs. 100,000.
facts.plaintiff_claim: Payment of Rs. 100,000 was an independent transaction and not subject to conditions of subsequent offers.

jurisdiction.plaintiff_argument: Part of the cause of action arose in Quetta.
jurisdiction.defendant_argument: No part of the cause of action arose in Quetta, and W.P.I.D.C. had no subordinate office in Quetta.
jurisdiction.court_ruling: Quetta Court lacked jurisdiction as no part of the cause of action arose there and W.P.I.D.C. had no subordinate office in Quetta.

interpretation_of_law.explanation_ii: Corporation can only be sued where its principal office is located or where it has a subordinate office and part of the cause of action arises.

key_arguments.plaintiff: Payment was made in Quetta, offer was made in Quetta, and acceptance was received in Quetta.
key_arguments.defendant: Payment was encashed in Karachi, and no part of the contract was formed in Quetta.

court_decision.reasoning: No part of the cause of action arose in Quetta, and W.P.I.D.C. had no subordinate office in Quetta. Explanation II of Section 20, C.P.C., requires both conditions to be met for jurisdiction.
court_decision.outcome: Appeal dismissed with no order as to costs.
